turns.content: What is the current global temperature increase compared to pre-industrial levels?

As of 2023, global temperatures have increased by approximately 1.2°C compared to pre-industrial levels (1850-1900). This warming has accelerated in recent decades, with the last decade (2014-2023) being the warmest on record. Scientists measure this using a combination of land and ocean temperature data.

The main cause of global warming is the increase in greenhouse gas emissions, particularly CO2, which has risen from 280 parts per million (ppm) in pre-industrial times to over 410 ppm in 2023. About 75% of these emissions come from burning fossil fuels for energy and transportation, while deforestation and industrial processes account for most of the remainder.
